intro: Neuracanthus neesianus, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its strap-shaped leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant is often found in coastal and forested areas, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its fibrous leaves have been historically used by Māori for weaving and other traditional purposes. Neuracanthus neesianus plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, supporting various pollinators and contributing to biodiversity.
